awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: Surviving Cybersecurity and Privacy Threats in Wearable Mobile Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Smart wearable devices, such as smart watches, are very popular and fast replacing their traditional non-smart counterparts. By means of various high-precision on-board sensors, these devices capture rich contextual information about the wearer and his environment to enable several new and useful applications. However, this diverse set of on-board sensors also provides an additional attack surface. Access to these sensors, if not controlled appropriately, can be used as a side-channel by an adversary keen on obtaining private and sensitive information belonging to the wearer. Moreover, active misuse detection and resistance of these wearable device sensors is not straightforward. There is currently a lack of understanding of the various side-channel security vulnerabilities that are possible due to wearable devices and there is an urgent need to study the means for continuously protecting against them. The research in this project addresses this very timely topic.

The goal of this research is twofold: first, to demonstrate that wearable devices enable novel side-channel security and privacy threats, and second, to design continuous authentication techniques and adaptive access control mechanisms to survive these threats. Specifically, this research will evaluate private data inference and wearer tracking threats in wearable devices that utilize unprotected sensors as side-channels. This will be accomplished by designing appropriate learning-based classification and prediction mechanisms that can be used by an adversary for inferring sensitive data. On the protection front, this project will develop a multi-sensor activity and identity classification framework. This framework will leverage rich contextual sensor data (e.g., fine-grained movements, application usage and critical body parameters) to enable continuous identification and authentication of legitimate wearers and their activities. 

By studying security and privacy preferences of a diverse population of users, this research will develop usable activity-based access control tools for this new wearable device paradigm. A significant research thrust of this project is to develop adaptive data-sharing mechanisms for dynamically regulating access to sensor data based on the wearers' security preferences, current context and perceived threats. Such mechanisms will serve as a good middle-ground between giving full access (no security) and making manual decisions for each access (poor usability). This project involves industry collaborators to facilitate adoption of research outcomes into the future design and development of wearable devices. Research results, including proof-of-concept applications, will be publicly available to allow dissemination, early industry adoption and integration with curricula.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Modern wearable devices enable novel context-based applications by capturing fine-grained contextual information about the wearer and his/her environment using a variety of high-precision on-board sensors. However, this diverse set of sensors also expose a significant attack surface, which can be exploited by malicious software and services operating on these devices to compromise users' privacy and cybersecurity. The overarching research goal of this project, thus, was to first demonstrate that unrestricted and unregulated sensing by means of wearable devices (and its on-board sensors) can adversely impact the cybersecurity and privacy of wearers, and second, to design effective protection mechanisms against the same. In line with these goals, the project accomplished the following specific objectives:

(i) New attack/inference frameworks that employ data sensed by wearable device sensors to infer sensitive user information: In this direction, the project first investigated the feasibility of private information leakage from cyber-connected user-interfaces such as mobile touchpads, external QWERTY keyboards and ATM keypads. Specifically, the project designed machine learning based keystroke detection and inference frameworks that employed zero-permission sensors such as accelerometers, gyroscopes and ambient light sensors on-board modern wrist wearables to infer the keys typed by users (or wearers) on these interfaces. The main reason for targeting these sensors in the proposed attack frameworks was due to the fact that most modern mobile operating systems lack appropriate access control and protection measures regulating these sensors, and are thus more vulnerable to misuse. Extensive empirical evaluation of the proposed keystroke inference frameworks using data collected from human subject participants showed that they are not only fairly accurate in inferring keystrokes, but also comparable (and sometimes better) in terms of inference accuracy to other similar attack vectors. The project then investigated the feasibility of private information leakage from physical user-interfaces such as writing pens and lock dials. The project specifically studied the feasibility of inferring secret unlock combinations (or keys) on circular lock dials using the gyroscope motion sensor on wrist-wearables as an information side-channel and showed that the designed attack framework can significantly reduce the key search space, thus impacting the physical security provided by these locks. Following that, the project also studied the feasibility of inferring various types of handwritten information from the motion data sampled from the accelerometer and gyroscope sensors on-board wrist wearables. In summary, by means of this sustained multi-year effort, this project demonstrated that data from seemingly innocuous sensors on-board wearable devices (especially, wrist wearables) can be misused to infer extremely sensitive information and context about the user (or wearer).

(ii) New protection mechanisms against threats to user-privacy from wearable device sensors: In this direction, the project comprehensively investigated two different protection paradigms against the above threats: (a) run-time protection, and (b) design-time protection. Run-time protection mechanisms investigated in the project focused on designing and implementing accurate and efficient techniques to first detect sensitive activities and then appropriately regulate corresponding wearable devices sensor information flows to prevent sensitive data leakage. Design-time protection mechanisms focused on appropriately modifying the interfaces or user-interactions with these interfaces to protect against sensitive data leakage. In addition to comprehensively evaluating the performance of these techniques (in protecting against unauthorized information leakage), this project also evaluated the usability of these proposals by conducting extensive user-studies. To further understand user-perception and awareness about mobile motion-sensor related privacy risks, and how these vary across different user demographics, this project also conducted a structured and comprehensive user-study involving users from diverse backgrounds. This user-study also shed light on users' expectations from defense mechanisms that can protect against such threats to their privacy. Lastly, this project also comprehensively investigated the feasibility of employing motion sensor data from wrist-wearables to enable continuous activity-based user-authentication.

Broader Impacts:This project provided significant research opportunities and support to several graduate (doctoral) students, including two female PhD students. In addition to graduate students, this project provided technical development and research training opportunities to four high-qualified undergraduate students, including two minority (Hispanic) students through separately requested REU supplements. The project's outcomes have been disseminated to professional communities by means of highly refereed journal and conference publications and research reports. Anonymized datasets and prototype source codes have been made publicly available to interested researchers and engineers in the community for ease of replicability. Some of the significant research findings of this project have also been shared with the general community (including consumers and technology enthusiasts) through appropriate institutional press releases and press-coverage by online/news media companies. Lastly, the project's research outcomes have thrown significant light on the security and privacy challenges arising from modern wearable technology, with the hope that these results will enable development of more secure and privacy-preserving mobile and wearable software and hardware technology.
